conclusion: The problem involves determining the magnitude of the electrostatic force experienced by a point charge \( q \) placed at the midpoint between the plates of a parallel-plate capacitor.

The formula for the electrostatic force between two point charges is \( F = k \frac{q_1 q_2}{r^2} \), where \( k \) is Coulomb's constant, \( q_1 \) and \( q_2 \) are the charges, and \( r \) is the distance between them.

The image shows a parallel-plate capacitor with a positive charge \( +Q \) on one plate, a negative charge \( -Q \) on the other plate, and a point charge \( q \) placed at the midpoint between the plates.
The distance \( r \) between the point charge \( q \) and one of the plates is half the distance \( d \) between the plates, so \( r = \frac{d}{2} \).
Substituting \( d = 10 \, \text{m} \), the distance \( r \) is calculated as \( r = \frac{1}{2} \times 10 \, \text{m} = 5 \, \text{m} \).
The formula for the electrostatic force \( F \) is applied as \( F = k \frac{q q}{r^2} \).
Substituting \( r = 5 \, \text{m} \) into the formula, \( F = 8.99 \times 10^9 \, \text{N} \cdot \text{m}^2/\text{C}^2 \times \frac{q q}{(5 \, \text{m})^2} \).
The final expression for the force is \( F = \frac{8.99 \times 10^9 \, \text{N} \cdot \text{m}^2/\text{C}^2 \times q^2}{25} \).
